CoreData Python Example Applications

  • dumplog - Dumps CoreData log files to stdout.
  • extractlog - Read Data and Saves to Logfiles
  • gazeintersection_with_screen - Prints the gaze intersection with a screen in pixel coordinates.
  • netclient - Receives UDP packets and prints them to stdout.

dumplog - Dumps CoreData log files to stdout.

The dumplog console application reads data from binary faceLAB/DSS log file(s) and then prints it to stdout as fixed width text.

Usage

  dumplog.py [options] log_directory

Dumps log files in text format to stdout. Each set of fields will have a
column header displayed. For sparse data this will mean the output will
contain multiple column headers each time the sparse data appears and
disappears.

- log_directory is the directory containing CoreData log files. All .fll
    files in this directory will be merged. Note that the folder must
    contain exactly a one set of faceLAB/DSS logfiles.

Example:
  dumplog.py c:\test_data


Options:
  -h, --help  show this help message and exit

extractlog - Read Data and Saves to Logfiles

The extractlog application reads log files and saves a portion of the data to another set of log files.

Usage

  extractlog.py [options] log_directory output_directory

Extracts a portion of log files to binary files under the directory
specified by output_directory. The portion can be specified
using start and end frame numbers. If the --with-annotation-id switch is supplied
then only frames with an annotation id are extracted.

- log_directory is the directory containing CoreData log files. All .fll
    files in this directory will be merged. Note that the folder must
    contain exactly a one set of faceLAB/DSS logfiles.
- output_directory is the the name of a directory to write log files to.

Example:

extractlog.py --start-framenum 100 --end-framenum 199 c:\test_data c:\test_data_100_199

Will extract all frames in the range 100 to 199 inclusive from the log files in
c:\test_data to log files in the existing directory c:\test_data_100_199


Options:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  -s START_FRAME_NUM, --start-framenum=START_FRAME_NUM
                        first frame number to extract
  -e END_FRAME_NUM, --end-framenum=END_FRAME_NUM
                        last frame number to extract

gazeintersection_with_screen - Prints the gaze intersection with a screen in pixel coordinates.

The file logconverter.cpp converts binary logfile data into text format. The tool converts the specified logfile, or a list of the logfiles into a text version in the same folder. Text logfiles are column formatted, allowing them to be easily read into MATLAB or EXCEL.

Usage

  gazeintersection_with_screen.py [options] log_directory [label]

Prints to stdout the frame number and pixel x and y coordinates for the frames that the
subject's gaze intersected the world item with the supplied label.

- log_directory is the directory containing CoreData log files. All .fll
    files in this directory will be merged. Note that the folder must
    contain exactly a one set of faceLAB/DSS logfiles.

- label is the world item label. If not supplied then the list of world item
    labels that have a pixel gaze intersection are printed.

Example 1:
    gazeintersection_with_screen.py c:\test_data

    A list of world item labels with gaze intersections in pixel co-ordinates
    is printed to stdout.

Example 2:
    gazeintersection_with_screen.py c:\test_data "Plane (1)"

    A CSV list of framenumber, pixel x and pixel y positions is printed to stdout.


Options:
  -h, --help  show this help message and exit

netclient - Receives UDP packets and prints them to stdout.

The program receives faceLAB/DSS packets transmitted over UDP.

Usage

  netclient.py [options]

Listens on the DEFAULT_PORT_NUMBER for UDP packets and deserializes
them and prints their contents as text to stdout.


Options:
  -h, --help  show this help message and exit
